formatted_items.arguments:
{
  "to": ["emily.harris@greenleafwellness.org"],
  "subject": "Evidence-Based Strategies for Treating Anxiety Disorders",
  "body": "Dear Dr. Harris,

Thank you for getting in touch. Below is a concise evidence-based framework you can apply when working with clients who present with anxiety disorders. Everything comes from the latest CBT literature and the reference material I have consolidated in my Notion workspace.

1. Initial Assessment
   • Use brief, validated scales (e.g., GAD-7, BAI, OCI) alongside a functional analysis of triggers, thoughts, emotions, behaviours and physiological cues.
   • Rule out medical contributors (thyroid, cardiac, substance-induced anxiety) and co-morbid mood or trauma disorders.

2. Psycho-education
   • Explain the fight-or-flight response, the role of safety behaviours and avoidance, and how exposure plus cognitive work restores a sense of control.
   • Normalise anxiety as a protective system that has become hypersensitised.

3. Core CBT Interventions
   a) Cognitive Restructuring
      – Identify automatic thoughts, estimate evidence for/against, generate balanced alternatives.
      – Use thought records or the “ABCDE” worksheet (Activating event, Beliefs, Consequences, Disputation, Effect).
   b) Exposure Therapy (In-Vivo & Interoceptive)
      – Co-create a graded hierarchy; start with moderate items (Subjective Units of Distress ≈ 40–50).
      – Emphasise inhibitory-learning: vary context, remain until distress decreases ≈ 50 % or until client habituates.
   c) Coping Skills & Relapse Prevention
      – Diaphragmatic breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, 5-senses grounding.
      – Problem-solving steps: define, brainstorm, weigh pros/cons, plan, evaluate.
      – Develop a “coping card” with early-warning signs & skills to deploy.

4. Adjunctive Techniques
   • Mindfulness-based exercises (3-minute breathing space, body scan) to reduce experiential avoidance.
   • Behavioural activation when anhedonia or depression co-occurs.
   • Lifestyle: sleep hygiene, limit caffeine, regular exercise (150 min/wk at moderate intensity).

5. Recommended Reading & Tools
   • Clark & Beck – The Anxiety and Worry Workbook (2nd ed.)
   • Greenberger & Padesky – Mind Over Mood (2nd ed.)
   • Barlow – Anxiety and Its Disorders (2021)
   • My Notion page “Cognitive-Behavioral Techniques for Anxiety” – contains case vignettes, worksheets and step-by-step exposure templates. Let me know if you’d like shared access.

Please feel free to reach out if you’d like to discuss a specific case or need further resources. I hope this material proves useful to you and your team at GreenLeaf Wellness.

Warm regards,

[Your Name], PhD, LPC
Clinical Psychologist
[Phone | Optional]
"
}

formatted_items.content: I’ve sent Dr. Harris a concise, evidence-based CBT framework with practical tips, assessment guidance, exposure protocols, coping-skills suggestions, and a short reading list—all drawn from your Notion pages on anxiety. Let me know if you’d like any tweaks or follow-ups!
